definition: Personally identifiable financial information about a consumer that is not publicly available, collected by financial institutions in connection with providing financial products or services. Core protected data category defining the scope of GLBA Financial Privacy Rule and Safeguards Rule protections.
official_description: GLBA defines NPI in Regulation P Section 1016.3 as personally identifiable financial information that is nonpublic. NPI encompasses three primary categories: (1) Information consumer provides to obtain financial product or service - applications and forms, loan applications, credit card applications, account opening documents, financial statements, employment information, income verification, Social Security number (SSN), date of birth, driver's license number, passport number, address, phone numbers, email addresses; (2) Information resulting from transactions involving financial product or service - account numbers, account balances, transaction history, payment history, credit card purchase history, check account activity, loan payment schedules, investment account holdings, mutual fund portfolios, wire transfer records, account interest rates, fees, overdraft records, ATM withdrawals; (3) Information otherwise obtained in connection with providing financial product or service - credit reports and credit scores, creditworthiness assessments, fraud risk scores, behavioral scoring, customer segmentation data and lists, marketing preference information, service usage patterns, financial condition analysis, employment verification records, benefit statements. NPI does NOT include: information lawfully available from public sources (government records, courthouse records, public registries, published directories, news articles, SEC filings, court documents); properly de-identified or aggregated data where individuals cannot be reasonably re-identified through reasonable efforts; information that has been effectively de-identified (Safe Harbor standard per HIPAA); information in contexts where no financial product/service relationship exists. Protection requirements apply whether NPI is structured data in databases, unstructured data in documents/emails/logs, backup copies, archived data, or temporary processing files. Includes metadata and system logs containing customer identifiers even if core data not present.

definition: Information collected by financial institutions about customers in ongoing relationships, subject to heightened privacy protections under GLBA Regulation P compared to one-time consumer transactions. Includes broader scope of NPI and extends protections throughout customer relationship.
official_description: GLBA distinguishes between consumer and customer for application of privacy protections. Consumer is an individual who obtains or has obtained financial product or service from institution for personal, family, household purposes. Customer is consumer with whom institution has ongoing relationship. Customer information includes all NPI relating to customer and includes information about customer in institution's possession and information about customer in possession of service providers. Customer information relationships are continuous for duration of relationship and may extend beyond relationship for certain purposes. Customer information receives higher protection level under Financial Privacy Rule because ongoing relationship typically involves more detailed financial information. Customer relationships trigger: annual privacy notice requirement (unless FAST Act exemption applies), ongoing opt-out rights for information sharing, annual reminder of opt-out availability, customer access to institution's privacy policy, ongoing data protection obligations. Customer information use restricted to purposes authorized by customer or permitted by GLBA. Sharing limitations apply to customer information - institution cannot share with non-affiliates without customer opt-out right. Service provider relationships with customers require written contracts with GLBA safeguard requirements. Customer information retention policies must document how long information retained and destruction procedures.

definition: Payment card account numbers, personal identification numbers (PINs), card validation codes (CVV), and related payment card data requiring protection under both GLBA Safeguards Rule and PCI Data Security Standard (PCI DSS), with specific encryption and handling requirements.
official_description: Payment card information (PCI) includes: full account numbers, card expiration dates, card validation codes (CVV/CVC on back, CID on front), cardholder name, PIN, and related authentication data. PCI falls within NPI definition under GLBA requiring Safeguards Rule protection. Additionally, PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard) established by payment card networks (Visa, MasterCard, Discover, American Express) imposes requirements that often exceed GLBA requirements. GLBA institutions handling payment card data must comply with both GLBA Safeguards Rule AND PCI DSS requirements. GLBA Safeguards Rule requires encryption of payment card data at rest (AES-256) and in transit (TLS 1.2+); multi-factor authentication for access; vulnerability assessments; penetration testing; vendor oversight if card data processed by third parties; breach notification if encrypted data compromised (if encryption defeated). PCI DSS requirements include: cannot store PIN or CVV after transaction; cannot store full account number unencrypted; must encrypt in-transit transmission; must isolate payment processing systems; must log and monitor access; must regularly test security; annual penetration testing required; quarterly vulnerability scanning; level 1 PCI DSS compliance (highest standard) for institutions processing large volumes; assessment and audit requirements; vendor compliance requirements. Conflict resolution: comply with whichever is more stringent requirement on each issue.

definition: Health information or health-related data collected by financial institutions in connection with financial products or services, including health insurance information, medical expense data, pharmacy information, and health savings account (HSA) data, subject to both GLBA protections and HIPAA Privacy Rule (if applicable).
official_description: Health information in financial context includes: health insurance policy information, health insurance claims data, prescription/pharmacy information, medical expense payment information, health savings account (HSA) data, disability/workers compensation information, health-related benefits information. When financial institution obtains health information in connection with financial products/services, that information qualifies as NPI under GLBA requiring Safeguards Rule protection. Health information also often triggers HIPAA Privacy Rule if institution acts as Business Associate to healthcare provider or health plan. GLBA and HIPAA have different scopes but may overlap. GLBA Safeguards Rule applies to health information held by financial institution regardless of HIPAA applicability. HIPAA Privacy Rule applies if institution is Business Associate of HIPAA-covered entity. When both apply, must comply with stricter requirement on each issue. Common scenario: bank acting as Business Associate to health plan or healthcare provider - must comply with both GLBA and HIPAA. Another scenario: bank collecting health information about borrower for lending purposes (disability status, health condition) - GLBA applies but not HIPAA unless also Business Associate.
